trans-unit.source: Unit Testing in .NET Core
trans-unit.target: Unit Testing in .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Unit Testing in .NET Core
trans-unit.target: Unit Testing in .NET Core

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Unit Testing in .NET Core
trans-unit.target: Unit Testing in .NET Core

trans-unit.source: By [Steve Smith](http://ardalis.com) and [Bill Wagner](https://github.com/BillWagner)
trans-unit.target: By [Steve Smith](http://ardalis.com) and [Bill Wagner](https://github.com/BillWagner)

trans-unit.source: .NET Core has been designed with testability in mind, so that creating unit tests for your applications is easier than ever before.
trans-unit.target: .NET Core has been designed with testability in mind, so that creating unit tests for your applications is easier than ever before.

trans-unit.source: This article briefly introduces unit tests (and how they differ from other kinds of tests).
trans-unit.target: This article briefly introduces unit tests (and how they differ from other kinds of tests).

trans-unit.source: Linked resources demonstrates how to add a test project to your solution and then run unit tests using either the command line or Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Linked resources demonstrates how to add a test project to your solution and then run unit tests using either the command line or Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Getting Started with Testing
trans-unit.target: Getting Started with Testing

trans-unit.source: Having a suite of automated tests is one of the best ways to ensure a software application does what its authors intended it to do.
trans-unit.target: Having a suite of automated tests is one of the best ways to ensure a software application does what its authors intended it to do.

trans-unit.source: There are many different kinds of tests for software applications, including integration tests, web tests, load tests, and many others.
trans-unit.target: There are many different kinds of tests for software applications, including integration tests, web tests, load tests, and many others.

trans-unit.source: At the lowest level are unit tests, which test individual software components or methods.
trans-unit.target: At the lowest level are unit tests, which test individual software components or methods.

trans-unit.source: Unit tests should only test code within the developer’s control, and should not test infrastructure concerns, like databases, file systems, or network resources.
trans-unit.target: Unit tests should only test code within the developer’s control, and should not test infrastructure concerns, like databases, file systems, or network resources.

trans-unit.source: Unit tests may be written using [Test Driven Development (TDD)](http://deviq.com/test-driven-development/), or they can be added to existing code to confirm its correctness.
trans-unit.target: Unit tests may be written using [Test Driven Development (TDD)](http://deviq.com/test-driven-development/), or they can be added to existing code to confirm its correctness.

trans-unit.source: In either case, they should be small, well-named, and fast, since ideally you will want to be able to run hundreds of them before pushing your changes into the project’s shared code repository.
trans-unit.target: In either case, they should be small, well-named, and fast, since ideally you will want to be able to run hundreds of them before pushing your changes into the project’s shared code repository.

trans-unit.source: Developers often struggle with coming up with good names for their test classes and methods.
trans-unit.target: Developers often struggle with coming up with good names for their test classes and methods.

trans-unit.source: As a starting point, the ASP.NET product team follows [these conventions](https://github.com/aspnet/Home/wiki/Engineering-guidelines#unit-tests-and-functional-tests).
trans-unit.target: As a starting point, the ASP.NET product team follows [these conventions](https://github.com/aspnet/Home/wiki/Engineering-guidelines#unit-tests-and-functional-tests).

trans-unit.source: When writing unit tests, be careful you don’t accidentally introduce dependencies on infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: When writing unit tests, be careful you don’t accidentally introduce dependencies on infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: These tend to make tests slower and more brittle, and thus should be reserved for integration tests.
trans-unit.target: These tend to make tests slower and more brittle, and thus should be reserved for integration tests.

trans-unit.source: You can avoid these hidden dependencies in your application code by following the [Explicit Dependencies Principle](http://deviq.com/explicit-dependencies-principle/) and using [Dependency Injection](https://docs.asp.net/en/latest/fundamentals/dependency-injection.html) to request your dependencies from the framework.
trans-unit.target: You can avoid these hidden dependencies in your application code by following the [Explicit Dependencies Principle](http://deviq.com/explicit-dependencies-principle/) and using [Dependency Injection](https://docs.asp.net/en/latest/fundamentals/dependency-injection.html) to request your dependencies from the framework.

trans-unit.source: You can also keep your unit tests in a separate project from your integration tests, and ensure your unit test project doesn’t have references to or dependencies on infrastructure packages.
trans-unit.target: You can also keep your unit tests in a separate project from your integration tests, and ensure your unit test project doesn’t have references to or dependencies on infrastructure packages.

trans-unit.source: Learn more about unit testing in .NET Core projects:
trans-unit.target: Learn more about unit testing in .NET Core projects:

trans-unit.source: Try this [walkthrough creating unit tests with xunit and the .NET CLI](unit-testing-with-dotnet-test.md).
trans-unit.target: Try this [walkthrough creating unit tests with xunit and the .NET CLI](unit-testing-with-dotnet-test.md).

trans-unit.source: The XUnit team has written a tutorial that shows [how to use xunit with .NET Core and Visual Studio](http://xunit.github.io/docs/getting-started-dotnet-core.html).
trans-unit.target: The XUnit team has written a tutorial that shows [how to use xunit with .NET Core and Visual Studio](http://xunit.github.io/docs/getting-started-dotnet-core.html).
